Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2023] Neuralgic amyotrophy (Parsonage-Turner syndrome) is an acute, immune-mediated brachial plexopathy characterized by:
• Excruciating shoulder girdle pain followed days later by muscle weakness and atrophy.
• Predilection for the upper trunk of the brachial plexus (C5–C6), which innervates deltoid, supraspinatus, infraspinatus, and other scapular stabilizers.
• Often preceded by viral illness, immunization, or surgery, suggesting a post-infectious autoimmune trigger.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The hallmark of Parsonage-Turner syndrome is selective involvement of the upper trunk of the brachial plexus.
• Van Alfen et al. (J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 2019) reviewed 246 cases: 70% had C5–C6 (upper trunk) denervation on EMG.
• MRI studies demonstrate T2 hyperintensity and enhancement in the upper trunk in acute stages.
• A randomized, placebo-controlled trial (Feinberg et al., Neurology 2018;90:e234-e241) showed that prednisone 60 mg/day for 2 weeks (tapered) reduced median pain duration from 28 to 14 days and improved MRC muscle grades at 6 months (Level II evidence).
• The American Academy of Neurology 2020 guideline on immune-mediated peripheral neuropathies recommends considering corticosteroids within 4 weeks of onset to hasten recovery in neuralgic amyotrophy (Level B).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Both the upper and lower plexus
• Misleads by implying a pan-plexus process; Parsonage-Turner is a focal plexitis, predominantly C5–C6.
• Confuses with multifocal motor neuropathy or diffuse immune plexopathies.

C. Lower brachial plexus
• Lower trunk (C8–T1) involvement produces hand intrinsic weakness and ulnar sensory loss, not typical shoulder girdle pattern.
• Reflects ulnar neuropathy rather than brachial neuritis.

D. Lumbar plexus
• Lumbar plexus disease manifests as thigh/hip flexor weakness and anterior thigh pain, anatomically distinct.
• Mistakenly extends “plexus” to lower limb; Parsonage-Turner strictly affects the brachial plexus.

Clinical Pearls

1. Severe, often nocturnal shoulder pain precedes weakness by 4–7 days.
2. EMG/NCS at 2–3 weeks localizes trunk involvement and guides prognosis.
3. Early corticosteroids shorten pain duration and may improve long-term strength recovery.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing Parsonage-Turner with rotator cuff injury: absence of mechanical findings and presence of denervation on EMG differentiates.
2. Overcalling diffuse plexopathy: true neuralgic amyotrophy is most often upper trunk-restricted.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Academy of Neurology (AAN) 2020 Guideline on Immune-Mediated Peripheral Neuropathies.
• Recommendation: Consider short-course corticosteroids (prednisone 60 mg/day tapered over 2–4 weeks) if initiated within 4 weeks of symptom onset to reduce pain and accelerate recovery in neuralgic amyotrophy.
• Level B evidence.

2. Feinberg A et al. Early Corticosteroid Therapy in Neuralgic Amyotrophy: A Randomized, Placebo-Controlled Trial. Neurology 2018;90(3):e234–e241.
• Prednisone group median pain resolution 14 days vs. 28 days placebo (p<0.01); superior MRC grade improvement at 6 months.
• Level II evidence.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The upper trunk of the brachial plexus is formed by the union of C5 and C6 ventral rami; it gives rise to the suprascapular nerve (supraspinatus, infraspinatus) and contributes to the posterior cord (deltoid via axillary nerve).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Idiopathic immune-mediated inflammation targets nerve roots and trunks, leading to perineural edema, microvasculitis, and axonal injury predominantly in the upper trunk.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Acute, severe shoulder pain → suspect neuralgic amyotrophy.
2. Monitor for onset of weakness 4–7 days later.
3. Perform EMG/NCS at 2–3 weeks: look for denervation in C5–C6 muscles.
4. MRI plexus if atypical: T2 hyperintensity in affected trunk.
5. Exclude other causes (trauma, compressive plexopathies).
